All v1 can move their position to V2The total supply of AAVE is 16M, of which 13M are redeemable by LEND holders with a ratio of 100 LEND per 1 AAVE. The remaining 3M will be allocated to the Aave Reserve and controlled by the AAVE  token holders, to incentivize the Aave Ecosystem growth and development. Funds allocation:
 30% on core development
20% on user experience development 20% on management & legal 
20% on promotions & marketing 
10% on unexpected costsAAVE and/or stkAAVE token holders receive governance powers proportionally to the sum of their balance. There are initially two powers associated with each governance token:

1- The proposal power that gives access to creating and sustaining a proposal.

2- The voting power which is used to vote for or against existing proposals.

Any user can choose to delegate one or both of the governance powers associated with a token, either through our governance portal or programmatically.

instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input: I have the exact same question as above. Where does all the income generated by aave go? I checked the governance fund contract, and it had ~$157k, while aave made $1.8mn in the last week alone.Thanks for the answer. Isnt the income of a financial lender computed as the difference of money made via lending and paid via interest to depositors? What is the meaning of income before you pay interest to depositors? Or is this extra income being paid to depositors because there arent many depositors?So basically the real profits of the platform are much smaller than $1.8 million n posted in weekly income? So the $167k in governance fund, increasing by roughly $10k/week, are the  profits/earnings of the platform?Thank you very much for the response, very appreciated LDR (loan to deposit) ratio for a bank to make money should be 80-90%, but its only 20% for aave. Are there any plans to increase utilisation? Because at 20% aave will barely make money to pay back depositors.That wasnt the question. A bank makes profits of x-y by taking x money from borrowers and paying y money to depositors. Now, if you have very little borrowing, like aave, your x-y is close to 0, which means no profits. X-Y for aave right now seems to be $10k/ week and thats very small. And its small because only 20% of all money is lended out. Note: I skipped flash loan income for simplicity.If you look at the governance fund, which is the profits of aave, youll find only $250k in it, and it increases by roughly $10k each week.Rates will only come down when more money is borrowed, right now only 20% is borrowed, there is no lack of money even now. If utilisation doesnt increases, more deposits will not lead to reduced rate of borrowings.No they wont borrow just because they get loans at cheap rates, and if they get loans at cheap rates then depositors will get cheap rates and theyll not be interested in depositing money in the protocol. Most people I know dont want to deposit already because interest rates are too low. Plus you cant bring down rates below traditional banking rates because then people will just cash out and deposit money in the bank.Interest rate of depositing/lending will always move together, but utilisation must become larger than 80%Interest rates for deposits/borrowings can only move together, but if you have high utilisation then you can bring borrowing rates lower without decreasing deposit rates, or in other words you can decrease the gap between the two, so again, utilisation must must must increase, period.If youre saying that aave doesnt have any idea or plans to increase utilisation then I understand that, but that doesnt mean its not important. I specifically wanted to know if there are any plans or estimates to grow utilisation Nope, it doesnt do that since AIP3 (or 2) I think. They simply put the money in a reserve fund.

I think the focus should be on increasing deposits which will reduce the rates of borrowingInterest rates depend on the forces of demand and supply. The demand is not in our control but the supply is. We can bring down the interest rates of deposits to bring down the interest rates of borrowings.Interest rates on deposits of stablecoins right now is around 5-10% which is extremely high compared to banks. They have like 0.5-1% interest rate on deposits. There's just the smart contract risk which slowly goes away as time passes. And the gas fee problem for which we need L2 asapThe interest rates of deposits is also not in our control but it will come down as deposits growWith this balancer pool proposal passing, apy for SM should grow to 10-12% . Let's see how long it takes to get thereOr will it be new money entering the balancer pool So it's either new aave that will enter the balancer staking or the aave from the safety module. I think eventually rates in both places would be equal , around 12% in each oneMight be a bit less for the balancer pool as there are other stuff like trading fees and balancer liquidity mining.In a day. Not sure about the time.In the aave eth balancer poolhttps://pools.balancer.exchange/#/pool/0xc697051d1c6296c24ae3bcef39aca743861d9a81/swapsYield would be great in the first week. Should make up for the gas fees lolIt requires aave balancer pool token, for which you have to deposit 20% eth and 80% aave in the aave balancer pool . Then you deposit the aave balancer pool token(which is the proof of your pool share) into stakingYield is 420% now. Should normalise around 50ish in a month?It gets automatically wrapped right?

Do we need to actively court these shareholders for any future proposal?I think the fact remains that the BOND team thought they did their due diligence to make sure that they were going to pass the proposal 100% but it didnt because apparently you have to reach out to VCs individually since they wont read governance posts by themselves, which seems a little crazy to me. I think this is going to make governance very slow and cumbersome...It doesn't seem sustainable that these VCs can hold so much voting power without any active voice from them.idk.... these are the rules of the AAVE token. whats the point in complaining about itwell idk. i see governance as a WIP for the entire ecosystem so it wont be great. my point is that unless you're proposing a coup, theres no point in complaining about large votersidk. i think a lot of these problems can be solved with just better communication.like i think bond would have been happy to have proposed without being collateral if the VCs just made it knowni understand that, but i also think its unfair to paint the other side as not acting in the interest of AAVEits not like the VCs want to sink their own shipthey have a legitimate disagreement i think. its just a matter of... why is this disagreement happening NOW?that its too risky to list as a collateral assetexactlywhy did it come after the votethats what makes no sense to meoh please. as if he has time for those kinds of conspiracies when hes invested in like 50 projectsimo your accusations really lack any evidence at all. we're already gotten the culprits of the vote wrong in the first place, and here we go againleave your vendetta for VCs at the door unless you have some actual evidencemaybe you should solve the problem thenseriously, try implementing quadratic voting. see what happens....no but to me you sound like a whiny kid. everybody understands that this is a problem, and lots of people are trying to solve it but it's a slow process. and whining about VCs is not productive at allhere we go....yeah im awfulpoor meyou should question why so little AAVE Is being used to vote in the first place. There's plenty of outstanding shares that can outnumber the NO votes. 

i think a large problem is that it is expensive to even vote in the first place and providing liquidity with your AAVE renders you ineligible to vote. from what i know, these are problems that are on the way to being solved.i dont really think governance can work efficiently until the underlying voting and communication channels are solidWell I was thinking more that time would solve the problem. instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
Hi, I'm creating a spread derivative DeFi protocol.

But to do so I need to be able to loan some LP tokens on aave market.
Would this be even possible and how I would go to propose this to the governance ?

Appart for me this is a good thing for aave as this will create new loaning fees for people who provide LP tokens (instead of just being used as collateral).No, I like to enable loaning AMM tokens (which it seems to me you currently can't).> why would anyone borrow an LP token that's accruing fees ? better to just borrow the underlying assets
No, because I'm doing spread, basically I want to short impermanent loss.
To do so I need to borrow LP tokens, then unpack them and add the underlying as collateral.

Like the whole point of IL is that you loose money compared to someone who is holding the underlying assets, let's assume this is longing IL.
Well, I want to short IL, so I do the reverse (borrow LP tokens and deposit underlying), then if IL kicks in I'll win money compared to the one holding LP tokens.(the actual thing isn't as simple, because with this example you would still loose money if both assets goes down in price, so you need to fully edge your underlying and only expose the spread, but it's doable)ok thx

instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
This post by the Keeper DAO about consensus building seems like a really interesting solution to governance
https://blog.keeperdao.com/introducing-keeperdao-governance/hi, I posted a recommendation to make a modest allocation to gauge vote incentives to help the Curve AAVE and SAAVE pools provide liquidity in USDC, USDT, DAI, and SUSD in the governance forum and would welcome thoughts and opinions around the concept.
https://governance.aave.com/t/arc-gauge-vote-incentives-on-convex-to-increase-stables-supply/5746Any further views on this point? I notice the pools have shrunk another 17.5%, meaning a decline of 37.5% since 3 weeks ago.
90% of AAVE's SUSD market comes out of the SAAVE pool, and it's over twice what is available to borrow.
If you scale the pools funding against the available DAI, USDC, and USDT to lend it's also not small. 
I'd like to get a view as to what people think and whether ther'es interest and conensus to advance the matter to the next step.https://governance.aave.com/t/arc-gauge-vote-incentives-on-convex-to-increase-stables-supply/5746Anyone actually comfortable with this bribe protocol? Why are they asking to stake AAVE in their token when they can see votes or ask for delegation? Anyone else concerned about potential rug, especially as no published audit still?They still can't seem to come up with a reasonable answer why they insist on staking when there's delegation built into AAVE governance. Have asked three times. At best, it creates unneeded smart contracts risk. At worst it exposed you to a rug. Either way, i fail to understand this design choice.Votium does not require you to stake anything. They see how your address voted (visible to all) and then you collect your bribe in an airdrop like interface... You can optionally delegate your vote to votium but that is a convenience and fallback in case you forget to vote. You can vote the desired way to earn the bribe or the other way to forgo it if you feel strongly. Importantly, you as an individual are always in control of both your principal token and your vote.

No matter how badly votium goes, your cvx is never in their smart contract. Worst case is you lose earned but not collected bribe if they get hacked/exploited.

Here you stake the AAVE or stkaave in a bribe smart contract. If those are malicious or erroneous, those tokens are at risk. I see no need to organize things that way when you can delegate or vote the desired ways. So why are bribe so insistent on taking possession? They say some comment about front running that makes no sense to me. Unless their contract blocks you from withdrawing once they accept a bribe, in which case your tokens could be voting for something malicious and have no control to stop it.

Custody and additional smart contract risk should require a strong justification. With delegation and publicly visible voting, i see no good reason to do this unless they are intending to not give your tokens back until after the vote. And not bothering to clarify that in tweets or Medium. That's the most innocent explanation I could find tbh. Unless you consider sloppy laziness as more innocent which is actually worse than malice in this space.If you don't vote you don't keep control. but even so AAVE governance has a built in delegation function, so they can still vote on your behalf.

Something feels off.

Thank you for explaining your rationale here. We would like to highlight that liquidity mining or adding additional assets have similar difficulties. Does liquidity mining drive only short-term growth? Does adding additional assets add tail risk to the protocol? Yes, they drive protocol revenue but how much is tough to pinpoint. All protocol changes will face this difficulty and that is why we called out metrics where we can drive the most impact.

One thing from most previous AIPs is clear, the Aave community has a long-term vision and is willing to experiment in the short term. Governance can and should evaluate Gauntlets impact quarterly and decide whether to renew our engagement.- Risk-adjusted yield for Depositors
- Capital efficiency for Borrowers
- Mitigate Depositor losses

Gauntlet will improve the metrics above without increasing the net insolvent value percentage or the slashing run percentage.Yes, they are measurable as we have done in the proposal. Creating controls and treatments and observing outputs is what we do to sanity check our models.Great call out. This https://gauntlet.network/reports/aave is the equivalent of a code review. What we are proposing is continuousAIP-34 Liquidation Bonus Updates is live for voting https://app.aave.com/governance/30-QmccRszk94JUyj3xGcBUxUzCo43jZDQYgesEULsudVjm9vSince AIP's are binary hoping all stakeholders vote in this Snapshot to help reveal the community preference. instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
I think that's not possible just yet:
https://governance.aave.com/t/proposal-persist-voting-power-for-aave-tokens-bridged-to-polygon/3927Although it's something that is apparently already being worked on:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m4yg4XdHB-YThe coding is happening here:
https://github.com/aave/governance-crosschain-bridgesThis is a common issue with dapps that initiate transactions that you then need to approve using your Metamask or whatever: that won't work for multisigs like Gnosis Safe and the like.

An old workaround that has done the trick for me in other dapps is initiating the transaction with my own account on Metamask, and instead of submitting the transaction, I look at the data field and copypaste those hex bytes into a new multisig transaction pointing to the same contract address and containing the same data. Once the signing is done by the required signers, the transaction that goes through should be perfectly valid.

are the fireblocks people here?interested to see if they'll respond to the posts in the forumhttps://governance.aave.com/t/add-fireblocks-as-a-whitelister-on-aave-arc/5753Narrator: They did not respondHi all - if you have a moment and have Aave delegated to you, we at Avantgarde Finance would appreciate your "YAE" vote on this proposal: https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/?proposalId=77

If it passes, it adds a function that allows for users to claim their stkAAVE rewards without passing a `to` address as a parameter; instead the rewards are passed directly to the address that calls the function (and has earned the rewards). This change allows for Enzyme vault managers to claim rewards on behalf of their vault, but has a wider application to any set of contracts that uses the same proxy architecture.

The code this proposal implements has been audited and approved. It passed a snapshot at the end of last year (https://snapshot.org/#/aave.eth/proposal/QmcgTovk982fcUTN17qtDyZ4oCoVGnKZJGuwMVtqspfphk). A full description of the change is here, along with the code itself: https://github.com/aave/aip/blob/Pending-AIPs/content/aips/29720ED10AEA-AIP-ADD-CLAIMREWARDSTOSELF-TO-INCENTIVES.md

instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
> 1. What's the scope of the emergency admin power? Who are the emergency admin signers?
emergency admin power can pause the lending pool
aave guardian elected members https://governance.aave.com/t/aave-guardian-elected-members/5772

> 2.  How can emergency admins be overrulled?
governance can set the emergency admin through the gov process and the new emergency admin can unpause
> 3. Why there are no docs about this kind of info?
the docs refer to it as guardian multisig (not explicitly mentioned as emergency admin so maybe confusing) but I agree it is not very detailed. I will update the docs, so all information is easily accessible and much clear.
> 4. Is the fallback oracle mantained and live?
The address of fallback oracle can always be queried from Price Oracle available in deployed contracts section in dev docs. The price from fallback is used only if source is 0 or price is negative. So fallback oracle prices are not actively updated rather main security focus is to keep asset price source up to date.
Anyway you can find fallback oracle here  https://etherscan.io/address/0x5b09e578cfeaa23f1b11127a658855434e4f3e09#code
> 5. Are there any kind of delays on governance votes for users to withdraw their assets before they go live?
Delays are based on type of proposals => https://docs.aave.com/developers/protocol-governance/governance#proposal-typesWhich time lock the proposal should be submitted is decided by the protocol and can be updated by the community.
For eg. Only pool admin can initialize new token in Aave market and the pool admin for main v2 market on ethereum is short lock executor. So, in this case a proposal has to go through short timelock executor else it cannot be executed/have no consequence. 
Contracts are verified on etherscan so you can read the value of delay, grace period etc there. Links to all executor contracts can be found  https://docs.aave.com/developers/protocol-governance/governance

instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
Hi I have a question around the power dynamic of Aave as a platform. 

A proxy contract is used to govern the platform correct? That means every update cannot be enforced upon users. Instead  a new version is deployed and then users have to get coordinated towards using it. That eliminates the threat of web2 platforms that could enforce more and more features upon to bind us to the platform and ultimately extract way more rent than we initially anticipated. So I like the decentralised approach of course.

But it brings up the question of what tools the governance contract really has to coordinate users towards a new update. For example if Aave wants to raise its fees how would that work? Couldn't users just keep using the old version?

And also what happens once a trillion is locked in the protocol, how could updates then be implemented? How do you make a trillion move to a new updated version? 

I guess the front end is a tool to coordinate but that is in control of the team rather than the token holders right?

So how does all of that work exactly? And how will it work in the future? Or am I missing something?

Thanks in advance for any clarification

instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
Why can't I borrow stEth through Aave? There is a TON of stEth in the reserve, yet I can't borrow it? It will force users like me to euler.finance which is less battle-tested than aave so that is not ideal. wstETH is Euler's 3rd most borrowed asset after USDC and WETH so there is significant demand for this. On top of that, I would assume it actually improves Aave's overall safety if people can hedge and take the other side of this, as your chance of incurring bad debt due to steth would decrease? Can someone please let me know if there are plans to enable this, it just seems really bizarre to meIt's kinda mind blowing, there is $2.5B of stETH in aave, it is the MOST supplied asset in the protocol, and it can't be borrowed!! usually I've been very impressed by aave's risk assessments but i'm just in awe hereI don't have 500 aave so I can't make the proposal - but it seems absolutely crazy from the outside looking in. IIRC the justification Aave provided on twitter for this decision was "we didn't think there was going to be borrow demand for stETH". I do not believe that, and even giving you the benefit of the doubt that assumption is definitely not true now - go check euler.finance for proof - the borrow APY for wstETH is ~5.5% with $32.5M worth of it borrowed (over 50% utilization rate). 

It is so obvious this is getting into systemic risk territory (not only for aave) but other protocols built on top of aave. From your governance "Due to uncertainty around the stETH peg, Gauntlet proposes increasing stETH liquidation threshold. This will allow borrowers using stETH as collateral with more buffer in case stETH continues to depeg, and thus decrease the chances of liquidation cascades that lead to insolvency on the Aave platform" https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/75/

What is the real explanation for not enabling borrowing on stETH. Every other large asset on your platform can be borrowed, but the largest one can't!? And there is a ton of risk around stETH - you have smart contract risk, trust assumptions, merge uncertainty (not only around if/when the merge happens, but possible forks) and you are limiting the market to weigh risk here. Maybe someone with more skin in the game can turn this into a governance proposal - totally bizarre to meYup, unfortunately that is the case now. So there's probably nothing that can be done. If borrowing stETH was possible all along, like is the case for all other assets, then market participants would have been able to short this all along and prevent this bubble in the first place bc there was false confidence and an incorrect assumption that stETH is pegged 1:1 with eth. Hindsight 20/20 i guess . Now that it is crisis mode I wouldn't suggest making it borrowable personally, but i'm not a risk expert or anythingKeep in mind steth was slightly over 0.98 eth when i originally posted this

instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
Hey guys, I'm Brian from Gamma Strategies, which is an active Uniswap v3 manager.  

If anyone is interested, I am writing a draft proposal (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lAHjZx8m4J-meswzTk1BypxIAZum-W-GQfurEHPn7U0/edit) for Aave that will allow the GHO-USDC LP position on Uniswap v3 to be allowed as collateral for GHO in an isolated lending market.

The ability to leverage yield farm this LP position has the potential to garner significant liquidity for GHO-USDC which helps its peg and will generate revenue for the DAO.  And the isolated lending market is an extra layer of precaution against depeg events or manipulation.

Happy to discuss further and get feedback from the community!  Much appreciated.

instruction: Detect the sentiment of the content.
input:
Hello Aave community - Trying to do some market survey from a mature DAO like Aave (plz dont ban me  ). 

What do people think about a partially anonymous forum? Has anyone censored their controversial ideas due to fear of social reprisals? What have you done if your idea goes against the big players in the DAO? Can partial anonymity be a way to start addressing group think?

I understand that social reputation is important in qualifying the ideas but, it also gets in the way of viewing ideas based on its merits. In certain cases, we censor our controversial comments because it goes against the grain of the majority of DAOs and we tend to not point that out because of fear of social reprisal. Again, this may get in the way of having the most effective decision as some ideas are not considered (and that consensus is a more of a capitulation than general agreement that we have the best idea.)

I believe that certain topics may require an anon space to assess the ideas by its merits rather than rely too heavily on the social representation (albeit it has an important role in the DAO). 

How do you think anon forums would impact the quality of forum discussions?Hey @MarcZeller  - do you have any thoughts about the above by anychance?Awesome! Thanks for the suggestion!Mind if I also get your take on it?

Good day H3lpfulBrother!
I`m Centrifuge Governance Facilitator and we are doing research about Governance, DAO and Delegation.
Can you point me out AAVE Governance Facilitator, please? I will be really grateful if he could help me with some information.
That would be really great!
Thank youHi
Who is responsible for Governance part in AAVE? For example: Gov-alpha (MakerDao) group..
I have general questions about the governance and delegation . Or in case if you can help me with answers that would be great too!@h3lpfulBrother
We are trying to find the best model for our delegation process, so we are researching information about governance, DAO and delegation.

1. How many active delegates do you have? How their vote power is distributed? 
2. What are the stats of Delegate involvement (i.e. voting, percentage of token supply delegated, number of proposals voted on). Do you track this?
3. Does Delegation help you to solve Governance problems? Is anyone doing something surprising with Delegates? Is something that you would like to improve or change?
4. How did DAO track and communicate about Delegate involvement? (i.e with tooling etc)
5. What is your assessment of the interfaces/tooling that community members can use to elect Delegates (i.e. ease for token holders to delegate, ease for delegates, how much do these interfaces affect the utilization of Delegates).
6. How do you involve the community to delegate? (This is not easy to convince them).
7. How you engage with your community (not delegates or entities)? I suppose that via Governance call. Any advise, help, suggestions how can be improved the governance call and how to engage more community in it ? 

Some of the questions i already found via your forum and tools, but would be great if you could answer them anyway. Maybe i missed something or you can point me out something relevant that i missed.Good day Pablo and thank you for your reply
I asked h3lpfulBrother and he said that i can ask here because this is the best way...The key is that i was looking for feedback not from a specific entity or group, but i was looking the feedback from AAVE team.
Most of the questions were addressed to AAVE team and i think that delegates are definitely not involved in:
- How AAVE involve the community to delegate?
-  Does Delegation help you to solve Governance problems?
and etc...> but Im not really understanding the reasoning to ask a specific team when Aave protocol is decentralized and not ruled or owned by us

this looks like a ping-pong game:
1. I have asked where is the best place and who could be the appropriate person who can help me with the answers... And i was told that i should use #governance channel. Ok.
2. Asked in #governance   and i was redirected (surprise) from here to delegates ( how they could answer some of the questions i really don't know...)
3.  Now i`m redirected for the 3rd time to another place..
Wow.. 


-  Does Delegation help you to solve Governance problems?
-  How AAVE involve the community to delegate?
These questions are clearly not for the community nor for delegates.

Just wonder how many times again i will be redirected... Just for example...MakerDao, SafeDAO replied to me without any problems..

Hello all. I'm currently researching DAO governance models and reading AAVE governance documents. I have a few questions regarding and really appreciate if any member can share some feedback.

As per my understanding, AAVE currently employs the governance v2 model. I noticed that a proposal for Aave governance v3 was voted on Snapshot two weeks ago, but an AIP or on-chain voting has not taken place yet. Should I consider Aave governance v2 as the latest document for my reference? https://docs.aave.com/developers/v/2.0/protocol-governance/governance#proposal-life-cycle

Regarding to Snapshot, as as per v2 documents, Snapshot voting is optional but highly recommended for consensus. However, within Snapshot settings, there is a min quorum set at 320K as well as 3 day voting period + 1 day voting delay. Since snapshot voting is not mandatory, I'm wondering how relevant this quorum and durations? Also historically, there are several snapshot votings took more than 5 days. Was there any update in 2023 regarding to duration?

Regarding to onchain voting, Level2 requirements are updated with proposal 106 - https://app.aave.com/governance/proposal/106/ - could you please confirm?

Sorry to ask many questions, but the confusion is that there are several documentations, not clear which one is the latest . so proposal 106 lowers the proposition threshold, quorum and vote differentials for long executor proposals, right?thanks for reply. Yes, I already checked governance forum, went through some of the discussions.
